author: Bengt Hansson

comments.message: It's the next step in the future of medicine, the interaction with robots specialized to do few actions could bring many advantages but as Kylan said, how do you make sure that this robot is not interacting with anyone else? Or is there any material that the robots are made of that can be washed easily and not getting it damaged?
This is a good idea actually because people will have a less likely chance to get Ebola but the thing is you would have to make sure that the robot does not interact with any other humans.

A recent Japanese news article on the subject:
http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/10/15/business/japan-robot-week-offers-new-approaches-nursing-care/

And a NY Times article giving more insight in pros/cans:
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/23/science/scientists-consider-repurposing-robots-for-ebola.html?_r=0

There are also exoskeletons, which probably could be combined with PPE:s to e.g cool the health professional.
summary: Given the massive amount of health professionals needed, risk and the probably long period they will be needed it would be prime-time to boost manufacture of caregiving robots. They can certainly take on several easy, or even more complicated, tasks. Off course it must be robust enough to disinfect.I don´t think they will be felt as much more alien than people in PPE:s. Not the most innovative idea and probably regarded as inhumane but given the circumstances....
title: Robot help
